Headline: HK Regulatory Timeline
Text: A curated list of the Regulatory events around Bitcoin in Hong Kong
Media Caption: Bitcoin Association of Hong Kong

Headline: First Hong Kong Bitcoin Meetup
Text: Bitcoin enthusiasts for the first time met in person at the Hong Kong Bitcoin Meetup.

Headline: First Hong Kong Bitcoin exchanges open
Text: The two first Hong Kong Bitcoin exchanges ANX and Bitcashout open to customers. Before, MtGox, Bitstamp and Bitfinex were servicing the market primarily.

Headline: John Tsang blogs about Bitcoin
Text: The Hong Kong Financial Secretary John Tsang becomes the first Hong Kong official to blog about the topic of Bitcoin.

Headline: Bitcoin is debated in the Legislative Council
Text:
Legislator Christopher Cheung 張華峰, representing the financial services asks: “Will the Government state its position on the Bitcoin clearly and openly, so that the industry can have something to go by?”
LegCo Library

Headline: Bitcoin is defined as a 'Virtual Commodity,' falling under the jurisdiction of the Customs & Excise Department.
Text: John Tsang: "Bitcoin is a commodity generated in the cyber world” and “neither electronic money nor a stored value payment facility." LegCo Library

Headline: Government warns about Bitcoin
Media:
Secretary for Financial Services and the Treasury, Professor K C Chan: “We have branded bitcoins as a highly speculative product and we call upon the public to be very careful.”
Information Services Dept

Headline: Customs & Excise warns of risks associated with Bitcoin
Text: The Customs & Excise Department exercises its jurisdiction over Bitcoin and sends out a circular to entities licensed by it. Customs & Excise Dept Circular

Headline: Joint Financial Intelligence Unit references Bitcoin
Text: The Joint Financial Intelligence Unit references a report by the FATF on cryptocurrencies. FATF/JFIU

Headline: Secretary for Financial Services rejects demands for more regulation
Text: Secretary for Financial Services & the Treasury Prof KC Chan says "more Bitcoin regulation is not needed." Information Services Dept

Headline: HKMA refers to Bitcoin as 'cryptocurrency'
Text: In the "Blockchain Whitepaper" written by ASTRI and commissioned by the HKMA Bitcoin is labelled a 'cryptocurrency' HKMA

Headline: SFC warns of ICOs
Text: The Securities and Futures Commission warns of the dangers of ICOs and that some of these tokens do constitute securities.

Headline: HKMA refers to Bitcoin as 'cryptocurrency' again
Text: In the second edition of the "Blockchain Whitepaper" Bitcoin is again referred to as a cryptocurrency. HKMA

Headline: SFC asks exchanges to delist tokens deemed 'securities'
Text: The SFC began clarifying that some tokens are indeed seen as securities, and Hong Kong cryptocurrency exchanges were urged to comply as quickly as possible. SFC

Headline: HKMA reiterates that 'Bitcoin is not laundered'
Text: HKMA Chief Executive, Norman Chan reiterates their stance that Bitcoin is not money, but instead a type of commodity. As a commodity, it cannot be laundered. HKMA

Headline: SFC declared need to regulate 'virtual assets' and creation of new sandbox regime
Text: SFC CEO Ashley Alders declares Bitcoin a 'Virtual Asset' which the SFC has no jurisdiction over, but nonetheless aims to regulate. A 'sandbox regime' is announced. SFC

Headline: SFC declares Security Token Offerings 'Securities'
Text: Any person who markets and distributes Security Tokens (whether in Hong Kong or targeting Hong Kong investors) is required to be licensed or registered for Type 1 regulated activity. All usual due diligence, information and investor warnings apply.' SFC

Headline: Secretary for Financial Services labels Bitcoin a 'Virtual Asset'
Text: Secretary for Financial Services and the Treasury, James Lau talks about Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies a 'Virtual Asset.' Information Services Dept

Headline: SFC releases 'terms and conditions' for cryptocurrency businesses
Text: The Securities and Futures Commission releases a set of 'terms and conditions' which will apply to those cryptocurrency businesses voluntarily placing themselves under SFC supervision. SFC

Headline: SFC issues 'Approval-in-principle' to cryptocurrency brokerage for the first time.
Text: Hong Kong brokerage OSL becomes the first exchange to receive "Approval-in-principle" for brokerages and exchange services from the SFC. OSL Press Release
